name: 2-[(Z)-2-(4-chlorophenyl)-1-(2,4-dichlorophenoxy)ethenyl]-1,3-benzothiazole
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1205
Reason: The compound in question is composed of a benzothiazole core with additional substituted phenyl rings and an ethenyl linkage. The basic unit of benzene has a melting point of 5.5°C. Each chlorophenyl group contributes significantly to the rigidity and molecular weight of the compound, thus greatly increasing the melting point, estimated at +50°C for each of the two chlorophenyl groups. The ethenyl linkage will add some rigidity to the structure, but less so than aromatic rings, so its effect on the melting point is more moderate, estimated at +5°C. The benzothiazole core, with the nitrogen and sulfur heteroatoms, will contribute to stronger intermolecular forces and stability of the lattice, estimated at +40°C. The ether linkage has a relatively minor effect on melting point in this context and can be approximately considered negligible. Summing these contributions, the predicted melting point shift would be as follows: Basic benzene unit (+5.5°C) + 2 chlorophenyl groups (2*+50°C) + ethenyl group (+5°C) + benzothiazole core (+40°C).
Test (Predicted reason):
The compound 2-[(Z)-2-(4-chlorophenyl)-1-(2,4-dichlorophenoxy)ethenyl]-1,3-benzothiazole has several functional groups that influence its melting point. The basic unit, benzothiazole, has a melting point of around 100°C. The presence of aromatic rings and the presence of chlorine atoms contribute to an increase in the melting point due to increased molecular weight and enhanced intermolecular forces such as dipole-dipole interactions. The ethenyl group (vinyl group) is a polar group that can participate in dipole-dipole interactions, which might contribute to an increase in the melting point. The chlorophenyl group is a large, bulky group that can also increase the melting point due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. The presence of two chlorine atoms on the benzene ring also increases the molecular weight and the polarity of the molecule, which would further raise the melting point. The thiazole ring is a heterocyclic compound that can contribute to the rigidity of the molecule, which can increase the melting point. The presence of a nitrogen atom in the ring can also participate in hydrogen bonding, which would further increase the melting point. The overall effect of these groups is an increase in the melting point due to the combined increase in molecular weight, polarity, and intermolecular forces.
